entry.title: Adept Pelican Flex Theme widths
entry.summary: The width of the aside part and the main part didn't suit my needs. This article describes how I changed the max-width of the main container and shrinked the aside part.
entry.content:
All began with the last article where I posted a simple git command that was rather long and it wasn't displayed fully on my wide screen. This happend to relate to this issue https://github.com/alexandrevicenzi/Flex/issues/196 and the resulting commit https://github.com/alexandrevicenzi/Flex/commit/69fc4c39c10f021d6376c32a50ac777a54e03663 where a max-width: 760px; was added. In https://github.com/alexandrevicenzi/Flex/issues/274#issuecomment-886273776 alexandrevicenzi suggested a workaround using custom CSS to change the value. Fast forward, the workaround worked but the code still had a horizontal scroll bar. Thus I changed the width of the aside container (the left content) and moved the main content to the left. This resulted in the following custom.css data

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
        main article {
                max-width: 100%;
        }
        main {
                padding-left: 15vw;
        }
        aside {
                width: 15vw;
        }
}

The custom.css was placed inside my content/extra direcotry. I added the following content to my pelicanconf.conf

STATIC_PATHS = ["extra"]

EXTRA_PATH_METADATA = {
    "extra/custom.css": {"path": "static/css/custom.css"},
}

CUSTOM_CSS = "static/css/custom.css"

Now the full page has a smaller aside container and the main container uses the full screen width.

entry.title: Clone from Github using SSH and a corporate proxy
entry.summary: How to clone a Github Repository using SSH behind a corporate Proxy
entry.content:
So this is my very first useful post on this blog. You might already know this blog uses Pelican as base and is hosted on Github. To modify and add new content to the page I can either edit thing an Github itself and commit directly. But when I want to edit multiple files it's easier to edit all needed files and commit those and at the end push to Github. Github removed the password authentication, now stating

"Support for password authentication was removed on August 13, 2021. Please use a personal access token instead.".

To clone my source repository I use the SSH option with a private key instead. But how to specify which key the git clone command should use?

Following the reply from here https://stackoverflow.com/questions/6688655/select-private-key-to-use-with-git, I specified the core.sshCommand option. This might have worked when I am not behind a corporate Proxy...

But with this option to specify own SSH commands, we can also add ProxyCommand. This leads to the following command to clone the Github repo.

git clone git@github.com:<REPO_USER>/<REPO_NAME>.git --config core.sshCommand="ssh -i <~/.ssh/PRIVATE_KEY> -o 'ProxyCommand=corkscrew <PROXY_IP> <PROXY_PORT> %h %p'"
